I can speak for the Orbital Antares rocket failure. The Russian engine was refurbished by Areojet. They missed a very microscopic machining error in one of the bearing raceways. Turns out, the bearing race was tilted by less than a degree off center, one side was .0005" higher than the other side and this caused non-linear stress on a bearing that was supposed to be perfectly vertical. The bearings lifespan went from hours, down to seconds and eventually MELTED sending molten steel into the air inlets destroying EVERY propeller and turbine.. There is a cool story about how the Aerojet investigators thought it was dirty fuel (because there was debris inside the engine) but a coordinated investigation by NASA and Orbital ATK found that the debris came from the landing area (bunch of sand) while the engine was still "running" and that the actual failure was that bearing (Which cost Aerojet a LOT of money).

The reliability numbers you presented don't look THAT good. Both SpaceX and Orbital were not good. It looks like at the time SpaceX was about 4-5% failure rate. Orbital, according to your chart, is a wopping 20% failure rate (ouch!). SpaceX's rate has gotten worse with the September 2016 pad explosion: 2 failures in 29 launches, a failure rate of greater that 6%. These failure rates are unacceptable for unmanned launches, and would NEVER be contemplated for manned missions. SpaceX's released information about the September 2016 event raises more questions. The reason for the failure was given as an ignition in the helium tank within the LOX tank.The cause was the use of deep cryo (super cold) lox and the compsite wrapping in the helium tank. If the cause stated is in fact the source of the failure, it is troubling that the SpaceX design process permitted this design to become baseline. Their success rate so far is way worse than Atlas V, Delta, Proton & Soyuz. The risky choice of deep cryo LOX is also worrying. This concept has been known for 50 years or so, but never used. Do you think there is a reason for that? All of this suggests deeper problems at SpaceX. What are their processes? Are the following them? Is there verification of this? Are they following systems engineering best practices?

Destin, I've got a physics question for you, and I'm not sure how best to get to you... So I'll do it here.
I was retrieving my airsoft Glock Replica and after messing with the slide, I had a thought: what if you were to fire a pistol upside down with, say, a vice grip securing the pistol's slide behind the ejection port? The very design of the semi-automatic pistol requires that the expanding gases from the shell push back the slide in order to cycle the next round, since that's the path of least resistance. With this setup, I predict it'd have to push the body of the gun, as well as the magazine, forward in the same direction of the bullet, which would be weird.
I'm wondering if the gun would fire and cycle normally with recoil in a different direction, if the gun would simply jam since it wasn't designed for the gun to move the whole body of the gun, or if the gun would mis-fire catastrophically (which I feel would be least likely)

Regarding staging, and throwing away the extra mass of empty tanakge.

the 1963 Douglass ROMBUS booster was technically 1.5STO, since it discarded tanks on the way up.
Other designs didn't. Huge SSTO VTO rockets have been proposed. See the Convair Nexus, for 900 tonnes to LEO, or the Boeing AMLLV of '68 (1.5STO, discarded strap-on booters) for astonishing 2300 tonnes to LEO.
Later during the NASA SSPS studies, Boeing also proposed things like their Leo SSTO VTOVL for a modest 400 tonnes to LEO.

As Robert Truax said of his "Sea Dragon" 500 tons to LEO 2 stage booster, if you've got a patheticaloly small payload mass fraction, don't scrimp; make it bigger so you have a meaningful payload. He established that if you're talking about the same thing, there's no great deal more cost for a bigger thing. Size didn't affect cost, but parts count, design margins, and innovation were the killers in adding cost.

Hi Destin, in your video of the SpaceX crash I see the booster performing nominal while the disintegration of the upper stages goes on. So what CAN catastrophically kill the upper structure during nominal boost? I rule out an auto destruct misfire and am left with only three candidates, all of which are basically mechanical failure of the superstructure or of an upper stage cryogenic tank. One is dynamic misalignment of the stack by too large sideways course correction, think Challenger pushing through jet stream. Two is MaxQ failure, when the product of increasing airspeed and reducing air pressure maxes out to max dynamic stress. Three is pogo. Pogo haunted Saturn early on. All fluid rocket boosters are vulnerable to it. Pogo is a vertical tremor resonating that is self reinforcing by increasing fuel pressure, hence fuel and oxidizer flow and hence combustion, rocket engine output and hence rocket acceleration, closing the feedback loop. Your thoughts?

I grew up in the Race to the Moon era, my father worked on the unmanned probe side of the equation (Mariners and the like), and I eventually found myself working in space sciences early in the STS era (pre-Challenger). Given that background... I'm always relieved when a rocket gets its payload where it needs to be. I always expect them to fail since, especially in the 60s, it was shown that rocket science is often very unforgiving of errors, no matter how slight. It amazes me that these machines work as often as they do given all that can go wrong, but it's also reassuring that we've rarely let something go wrong in the same way twice.

You made a good point about this being a good time for these failures to happen. The Apollo 1 fire was a horrible tragedy, but it forced NASA to undertake a massive examination of their procedures and hardware with regards to safety. And they needed it - NASA hadn't had any big failures to that point and were getting sloppy. Without the improvements, the same problems would have probably turned up in later missions. Apollo 11 may not have made it to the moon, and Apollo 13 could have been much worse.

@SmarterEveryDay Thanks for putting this more eloquently than I could while explaining to people who were becoming cynical about the future of space programs after the latest incident. I explained that the engines themselves were adapted surplus Russian models based on earlier, more flawed engine designs from their aborted lunar program. That it was a burgeoning rocket program with a private company that was helping to lower the costs of payload to orbit. That you do indeed learn more from failures than successes and it's better to have them now rather than later when the stakes may be higher. It also helps to shake off complacency in engineers and flight controllers that became lethal with the Challenger and Columbia shuttles and reminds the public that as seemingly routine as space travel has become (at least to LEO), there are always risks. As the plaque on the Apollo 1 launch pad painfully reminds us, Ad Astra Per Aspera.

You sir, are amazing. It's a breath of fresh air to hear from someone knowledgeable in the field speaking to us on a level we can understand and expressing something that is as important in life as it is in the space flight industry. In an age where "everyone gets a trophy" and standards are lowered regularly in our school system (in the USA), we are veering farther and farther away from a very important aspect of life..... FAILURE. Without failure, we are never challenged to improve. We aren't shown where our minor flaws are and therefore are unable to make the needed improvements to advance ourselves. We as people need to "crash and burn" on occasion to know where our limitations are.
I urge everyone to go out tomorrow and try something you've never done before. Odds are you are going to fail gloriously, and not only is that OK and expected, but it's also exciting and a much greater learning experience than performing with perfection. The next time you fail at something, whether that be in the class room, on the field of play, or in matters of love and life, come back to this video and rewatch it. This should be everyone's reaction to failure.

I don't like the implication that Orbital Sciences' Antares rocket failure was caused by a Russian rocket engine. While there obviously was a failure in the engine (specifically a part called the turbopump), another possible cause being investigated currently is small bits of debris from the fuel tank that got taken in the engine, entered the turbopump which has very tight tolerances, and then destroyed the pump and therefore the rest of the engine failed.

Implying that the engines were the root cause for the Antares failure is premature at this point, considering the Orbital Sciences investigation is still ongoing.
